brief_summary.textblock:
This is a pilot study to test the hypothesis that biofeedback-mediated stress management
      (BFSM) training can be used to reduce distress and enhance quality of life in patients with
      non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Most patients with advanced NSCLC have significant
      physical symptoms, but even those who do not have physical symptoms have high levels of
      anxiety and depression.

clinical_study.brief_title: Biofeedback Training in Patients With Advanced Lung Cancer - A Pilot Study
clinical_study.condition: Advanced (Stage IV) Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)

detailed_description.textblock:
Biofeedback-mediated stress management (BFSM) involves helping patients to visualize the
      reactions which their own bodies have to stressful situations (increased heart rate,
      increased skin conductance, increased muscle tension, decreased digital peripheral
      temperature, decreased heart rate variability) and then teaching them to control these
      reactions, using standard stress management and relaxation techniques, coupled with
      computerized physiological feedback. The feedback helps patients to understand that deep
      relaxation is helping their bodies as well as their minds. Several small studies of BFSM
      training in cancer populations have been successful at helping with side effects of
      chemotherapy and radiation, but the effects of BFSM on distress and quality of life (QOL),
      particularly in NSCLC patients, have not been studied.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients with a new diagnosis of advanced (stage IV) non-small cell lung cancer
             (NSCLC)

          -  ECOG performance status 0-1.

          -  Plan to receive care at the Taussig Cancer Center.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Non-local patients, who will not have the ability to return for 8 study visits.

          -  Patients who are unable to speak and understand English readily,

          -  Patients with significant cognitive impairment.

intervention.description: Therapist and study assistant meet with patient, attach sensors, record physiologic variables and train the patient in relaxation techniques including deep breathing, guided imagery, progressive muscle relaxation, autogenics. Patient is given a handheld thermometer to take home and practice self-regulation between visits, along with a recording sheet to indicate how often practice occurs.

keyword: advanced (stage IV) non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)

facility.name: Cleveland Clinic Taussig Cancer Center, Case Comprehensive Cancer Center

clinical_study.official_title: Biofeedback Training in Patients With Advanced Lung Cancer - A Pilot Study

overall_official.affiliation: Cleveland Clinic Taussig Cancer Center, Case Comprehensive Cancer Center

primary_outcome.description: Keep track of how many visits the patients attend, how many they cancel, and what other difficulties are encounter in getting them to return for eight visits.
primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients that are able to return for eight visits of BFSM

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients able to complete the Quality of Life (QOL) questionnaires

secondary_outcome.description: Distress Thermometer questionnaire using a scale of 0-10. O meaning no distress and 10 meaning extreme distress.
secondary_outcome.measure: Assess changes in distress thermometer from baseline

secondary_outcome.description: Physical, social/family, emotional, and functional well-being on a 0-4 scale. O being not at all and 4 being very much.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on the FACT-lung questionnaire

secondary_outcome.description: Questionnaire to determine the levels of anxiety and depression that a patient is experiencing. The HADS is a fourteen item scale that generates ordinal data.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline of the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS)

secondary_outcome.description: 8‐Item depression health questionnaire based on a scale from 0-3. 0 meaning not at all and 3 meaning nearly every day.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline of the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-*8)

secondary_outcome.description: Compare the baseline measurement during the first five minutes of the session, the peak response to mental stress during the next ten minutes of the session, and the response during the self-relaxation period following the mental stress. An improvement would indicate success with biofeedback.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in baseline of digital peripheral temperature

secondary_outcome.description: Compare the baseline measurement during the first five minutes of the session, the peak response to mental stress during the next ten minutes of the session, and the response during the self-relaxation period following the mental stress. An improvement would indicate success with biofeedback.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in baseline of skin conductance

secondary_outcome.description: Compare the baseline measurement during the first five minutes of the session, the peak response to mental stress during the next ten minutes of the session, and the response during the self-relaxation period following the mental stress. An improvement would indicate success with biofeedback.

Compare the baseline measurement during the first five minutes of the session, the peak response to mental stress during the next ten minutes of the session, and the response during the self-relaxation period following the mental stress. An improvement would indicate success with biofeedback.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline of respiratory rates

An improvement would indicate success with biofeedback.
